Definition: A resource with economic value that an individual, corporation, or country owns or controls with the expectation that it will provide future benefit.
A fixed income instrument that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower.
Wealth in the form of money or assets, taken as a sign of the financial strength of an individual, organization, or nation.
A distribution of a portion of a company's earnings to a class of its shareholders.
The value of the shares issued by a company.
A pool of money set aside for a specific purpose.
The total value of goods produced and services provided in a country during one year.
A strategy used to offset or reduce the risk of adverse price movements.
A statistical measure of the changes in a portfolio of stocks representing a portion of the overall market.
A business arrangement in which two or more parties agree to pool their resources for the purpose of accomplishing a specific task.
A measurable value that demonstrates how effectively a company is achieving key business objectives.
The availability of liquid assets to a market or company.
The total market value of a company's outstanding shares of stock.
The value of all assets minus the total of all liabilities.
A financial derivative that represents a contract sold by one party to another party.
A range of investments held by a person or organization.
A limited or fixed number or amount of people or things, in particular.
A measure used to evaluate the efficiency or profitability of an investment.
The capital raised by a business or corporation through the issue and subscription of shares.
A marketable, fixed-interest U.S. government debt security with a maturity of more than 10 years.
